skill.summary: Create and manage mock API servers for development and testing.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and code examples. No executable code, file system access, network calls, or environment variable access. The skill provides guidance for users to create their own mock servers using established tools.

content.user_title: Create Mock API Servers for Testing
content.value_statement: Developers need realistic API simulations during development and testing. This skill provides guidance on creating mock servers with json-server, MSW, Prism, and custom Express implementations.
actual_capabilities: Generate mock API endpoints from OpenAPI specifications
Create custom mock responses with simulated delays and errors
Mock REST and GraphQL APIs using multiple tools
Implement authentication simulation and error conditions
Configure rate limiting and conditional responses
Set up proxy to real APIs with record and replay
limitations: Does not install or run mock servers automatically
Does not access external APIs or network resources
Does not modify local files or system configuration
Provides guidance only - user implements actual servers

use_cases.title: Simulate APIs During UI Development
use_cases.description: Create mock endpoints to build user interfaces before backend services are ready

use_cases.title: Test Error Scenarios
use_cases.description: Simulate network failures, timeouts, and various HTTP error codes for comprehensive testing

use_cases.title: Prototype API Contracts
use_cases.description: Design and validate API specifications before implementation begins

prompt_templates.title: Basic Mock Server

prompt_templates.prompt: Create a mock server from this OpenAPI specification using Prism with dynamic responses

prompt_templates.title: Error Simulation
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure mock endpoints that return 500 errors randomly and simulate 30-second timeouts

prompt_templates.title: GraphQL Mock
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up an Apollo Server mock with resolvers for users and posts queries and createUser mutation

output_examples.input: Create a mock server for a user API with GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE endpoints
output: Create db.json with users collection containing id, name, and email fields
Available endpoints: GET /users, GET /users/:id, POST /users, PUT /users/:id, PATCH /users/:id, DELETE /users/:id
Use query params: ?_page=1&_limit=10 for pagination, ?_sort=name&_order=asc for sorting

best_practices: Mirror production API structure and response formats for realistic testing
Use realistic data generators like Faker.js for comprehensive test coverage
Implement proper error responses including 400, 401, 403, 404, 409, and 500 status codes
anti_patterns: Using static mock data that does not reflect real API behavior
Ignoring error scenario testing and only testing happy paths
Failing to reset mock server state between test runs

faq.question: Which mock server tool should I choose?
faq.answer: JSON Server for quick prototypes, MSW for browser testing, Prism for OpenAPI specs, Express for full control, WireMock for enterprise needs.

faq.question: Can I mock GraphQL APIs?
faq.answer: Yes, use Apollo Server with mocks or MockList for dynamic data generation. Supports queries, mutations, and complex resolvers.

faq.question: How do I simulate network errors?
faq.answer: Use MSW http.get() with HttpResponse.error() or setTimeout for timeouts. Random error injection with Math.random() checks.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using mock servers?
faq.answer: Mock servers run locally. No data leaves your machine. Use in-memory storage or temporary files that are not persisted.

faq.question: Can I integrate with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, run mock servers as background processes in tests. Use MSW for Node.js integration tests or start Express server before test suite.

faq.question: How is this different from Postman mock servers?
faq.answer: This skill helps you create local mock servers you control. Postman mocks are cloud-hosted. Local mocks are faster and free.
